Retro_sch_inf: Yes - I had really great science teachers in high school. Probably the most formative experience in those classes was when we had to write an essay about why vaccination is important, essentially countering anti-vaxx arguments with an understanding of how vaccines actually work. I was never an anti-vaxxer but that gave me a lot of stability in my beliefs that we can actually trust scientific conclusions that are backed up by good quality research, and that "do your own research" is actually good advice - if you're reading peer reviewed papers, and not blogs. I also studied science at uni and in my first year we did a course on the scientific method, which cemented I think my way of looking at problems in this kind of deductive, experimental way. We covered big topics like climate change there, and then of course studying physics of course I "believe" in things like the atomic model, because I spent many years learning how complicated atoms really are (i.e. like learning that the Bohr model is an oversimplification, electrons don't spin around the nucleus, they exist in a probability distribution and pick a location when you observe them). My degree put me in the mindset that nothing we find through science is a law or final truth, it's just the best explanation we have until contradictory evidence crops up. It's just some conclusions are really obvious (e.g. gravity) and others are more tentative, usually because we can't actually see the thing (e.g. dark matter)
